'''Gigi Ibrahim''' is an [[Egyptian]] [[journalist]], [[blogger]] and [[socialist]] activist. She has been credited as being a part of a new generation of "citizen journalists" who document news events using [[social media]]. For this she was featured on a cover of [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] magazine as "one of the leaders" of [[Tahrir Square]] during the [[Egyptian Revolution 2011|Egyptian Revolution]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailycamera.com/features/ci_17742185 | title=The world at Boulder's doorstep | publisher=Daily Camera | date=4 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> Ibrahim however states, that while the internet was important for coordinating people in the ousting of [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]], "it was the battles on the streets that were crucial... It was their power that made the revolution." She is a member of the [[Revolutionary Socialists (Egypt)|Revolutionary Socialists]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?id=24165 | title=Socialist from Egypt to join debate about revolution | publisher=Socialist Worker (UK) | date=12 March 2011 | accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> and a graduate from the [[American University in Cairo]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/01/27/interview-with-an-egyptian-blogger/ | title=Interview With an Egyptian Blogger | publisher=The New York Times | date=27 January 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> where she earned a political science degree.
+
'''Gigi Ibrahim''' ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¬Ù Ø§Ø¨Ø±Ø§ÙÙÙ}}) is an [[Egyptian]] [[journalist]], [[blogger]] and [[socialist]] activist. She has been credited as being a part of a new generation of "citizen journalists" who document news events using [[social media]]. For this she was featured on a cover of [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] magazine as "one of the leaders" of [[Tahrir Square]] during the [[Egyptian Revolution 2011|Egyptian Revolution]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailycamera.com/features/ci_17742185 | title=The world at Boulder's doorstep | publisher=Daily Camera | date=4 March 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> Ibrahim however states, that while the internet was important for coordinating people in the ousting of [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]], "it was the battles on the streets that were crucial... It was their power that made the revolution." She is a member of the [[Revolutionary Socialists (Egypt)|Revolutionary Socialists]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?id=24165 | title=Socialist from Egypt to join debate about revolution | publisher=Socialist Worker (UK) | date=12 March 2011 | accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> and a graduate from the [[American University in Cairo]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/01/27/interview-with-an-egyptian-blogger/ | title=Interview With an Egyptian Blogger | publisher=The New York Times | date=27 January 2011 | accessdate=12 April 2011}}</ref> where she earned a political science degree.
